posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18690765
Scotch is from Scotland. Whisky usually denotes scotch styles but you also have Maker's Mark bourbon and the entire US legal code on alcohol which spells it whisky. Whiskey is an Irish spelling that became more common in the US with the migration, but if you read old letters, people use both interchangeably because spelling wasn't formalized until well after Webster's dictionary came out.

>>18690891
It started using unmalted barley because fuck English taxes and US Prohibition nearly killed the industry of over a thousand distilleries which ushered in the use of column stills. Pot stilled Irish is really good, though not usually as complex or funky as scotch, and shares a lot with American styles that aren't bourbon.

>Even with the same mashbills, the same amount of peat, the same time spent in oak, the same region where the barrels are stored,

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18690765
No e in scotch whisky.
No consistency everywhere else, it is not a protected term.
>Legal destinations for products
You'll find many are not protected, and many that you think are are actually only protected by trade agreement. And you'll commonly see legal loop holes.
Japanese whisky doesn't have to be Japanese. Bourbon doesn't have to be American or corn or any of that shit if it's intended for export.
I have consumed Australian champagne, bourbon, port, sherry, parmesan, cheddar etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18693750
Different stills.
Different cuts.
Barrel char level.
Barrel variation and barrel blending (some distilleries will save all the better barrels for more expensive bottles for example, or some will have less barrels so have a less uniform product ).
Yeast strain.
Chill filtration, colour, dilution.
Blending with older whisky.
Barrel finishes.
Secret disregard of certain rules, especially when it comes to the lattermost.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18694715
You try all of the other similar scotches. Including independent bottlings. Then you choose the best value among those. Then it gets discontinued and you start again (or it doesn't).
I'd probably go for the cask strength Smokehead (Caol Ila) over that. Or maybe the 6 isles (mostly Ledaig, cheap) or Compass Box Peat Monster (Mostly Caol Ila, a little cheaper than Laphroaig).

Or you can broaden your horizons a little and go for non Isla peat (like Glenfiddich, Loch Lomond, Benromach, Benriach, Tomintoul, Connemara, etc).
Or go for sherried peat like Longrow Red (or of course indie bottlings of any of your favourite Islays).

Of course have you tried QC or Lore? sherry? cairdeas? 3 oak? etc.

You definitely do not want to drink whiskey after brushing your teeth or rinsing your mouth with something minty.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18705779
It's 2 shelves down from bulleit, usually a 30% price difference. ~$25 vs ~35 depending on regional monopoly. It nails a lot of quintessential bourbon flavors and doesn't skimp on the proof. Not the best but the personal favorite of many along with Old Forester 100 and a few other old names with low prices offering higher proof than the legal minimum.

>>18706028
Red Breast 12 or 16, Mularkey if you can find it in your areas--they do a black barrel irish style that's really good, Green Spot, one of the newer ones like the Irishman. You may have to hit up a few good stores in nicer areas, irish availability is shit, especially when you get into single pot or the newer brands and the old ones that have been revived.

Or take a chance on something local with either an age statement or some assurance that it's old enough to be worth the price and was actually made by the distillery in question. There's good stuff out there that no one knows or cares about because it doesn't say buffalo trace on the bottle and gets you no clout among redditors. Also a lot of shit, but that's why the mixer was invented in 1920.

If you live in a state monopoly, the website may have a good inventory system and save you some trips and phone calls.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18708117
It's insanely popular but I prefer Ardbeg and Laphroaig. Old heads have said the quality on Lagavulin went down decades ago, I just wasn't impressed or feeling it. At least it tastes refined and expensive. Highland Park 12 is a good contrast to Islay with a different smoky character. I'd go with that one. Bruichladdich if you can find it, although the classic laddie is unpeated. Campeltown scotches are similar to Islay, it's right across the bay. There are a number of highland scotches with, comparatively, a hint of smoke that do interesting things. I remember Cragganmore tasting like it sounds, a dry and dusty attic with a fireplace burning in the floor below.

Most age statement scotches are good in some way, but some of the no age statement expressions are more interesting.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18710784
msg and Glutamic acid found in amino acid chains are very very different experiences and your body can barely handle concentrated msg without rapid headaches or tiredness. people will tell you that eating a few mushrooms or eating a few eggs is the same thing as having a tea spoon of umami powder because the glutamic acid content is the same, but msg concentrate is usually unbinded or has very weak bonds when added to food which makes your body absorb it much faster than it can process it whereas eating something like ham, you get the same glutamic acid content but its at the end of a very long peptide chain of amino acids which take much longer to break down before being absorbed. As long as you know this, you can understand why dialogue surrounding msg is so schizophrenic
>will it kill me??
unless you just down a bunch of it at once, no chance it kills you. Its naturally occuring in your body and you have ways to use and dispose of glutamic acid.
>brain damage
If you are really sensitive to it, then sure you might experience cell exhaustion or even the death of some braincells but theres no conclusive evidence that msg will kill your sense of taste or give you detectable brain damage.
>tldr
Its bad for you, wont kill you or cripple you. Msg concentrate and naturally occurring glutamate are an apples to oranges comparison

posts.com:
>>18703613
I don't like:

1) Processed cheese. Anyone who puts processsed cheese on a burger should get a firing squad. Unless you're a wagie at a fast food place, there are no excuses for doing this shit, ever.

2) Fried eggs. The sulfur taste of the yolk and the texture of the eggs clashes with the rest. If you made a thin omelette and folded it and put it on the burger that could work for a breakfast burger, but that's about the only reason I can think of.

3) Olives, marinated artichokes or pickled peppers: They're fucking great, especially in sandwiches, but they're too wet and don't pair well with other ingredients.

4) Any kind of weird shit mixed into the ground beef used to make the burger patties. The beef should contain only beef, and perhaps salt. MAYBE you can add black pepper. MAYBE. If the beef is getting old then crust it in garlic powder to mask the taste a bit, but that's only if the beef is on the edge of inedible. Don't drown it in a ton of butter or oil. Put the patties in a little oil to start with, but let them cook in their own fat.

5) Non-western spices/ingredients. Anyone who adds weird goop like gookchang should be given a free helicopter ride.

6) Excessive grease or sauce. I don't like a slimy burger, fuck off with that shit.

7) Fake meat. I don't need to say anything else.
A burger can contain any kind of meat, but it should have meat. Not sure what to call Portobello burgers.

8) Foods which are generally incompatible with the structure of a burger, or which don't pair with burgers well. Overly sweet things, for example. So, no donuts or strudels.

I can't think of anything else, is that a good list?

A lot of people also use too much oil. When I start heating the pan I put a drop of oil, probably half a teaspoon or less for a 12-inch skillet, in the center and then spread it around with a crumpled sheet of paper towel. No puddles or pools, just enough for a light oily sheen across the whole surface and I never have sticking problems. Credit where it's due, my mom showed me this technique and before that I did have trouble with things sticking because I was using too much oil.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
What annoys me isn't the limitations of cast iron - everything has limitations - but the people who fucking lie about it. The youtuber idiot "the cowboy kent rollins" or whatever the fuck he goes by is a perfect example of this kind of shill. He has videos where he takes a supposedly new pan and cooks bacon in it, then claiming that it didn't stick, even once.

Here's what happens to a new cast iron pan when you cook three slices of bacon in it. Each slice of bacon literally stripped the seasoning off the pan in the shape of each bacon slice.

That said,
>everything sticks even when copious amounts of oil/butter/etc are applied
>have to "season" it after every single use or it will shit the bed and die
>not allowed to wash it
I have other pans that are so well seasoned that I *can* cook bacon on them without any sticking or seasoning loss. However, when you get a new one, it can be a challenge to get to that point--and, once you get to that point, it's also possible to thin the seasoning so much in cooking with proteins that food sticks again. The key is, ironically, to actually wash the pan really well after cooking. Scrape off all the food, and use a chain mail rag if you need to, and cook in oil, at a very high heat, as much as possible during this time. Frying up potatoes is a really good way to build up seasoning.

Also, these are good points: >>18705004
>properly preheat the thing before cooking in it.
>>18705502
>When I start heating the pan I put a drop of oil, probably half a teaspoon or less for a 12-inch skillet, in the center and then spread it around with a crumpled sheet of paper towel.
I don't think too much oil is going to cause sticking, or at least I've never seen that happen when I cook with a lot of oil, but you really don't need much. Spreading a thin film of oil can even help prevent bacon from sticking. Preheating is KEY, though.

>>18705010
Preheating should not get it so hot it's exceeding the smoke point of your oil, wtf.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
mascarpone cream for panettone
4 egg yolks
120g sugar
30g water
500g mascarpone, +-100g depending on the desired consistency

mix the yolks with a stand mixer until they become airy
heat the sugar and water, remove when the water's evaporated and the sugar reaches 120°C and pour in the yolks as you keep mixing with the stand mixer
when the mixture cools down to about 30°C add the mascarpone 75-100g at a time and keep mixing
refrigerate and eat within 3-4 days

Let me introduce you panettone gastronomico, an antipasto to share with other family members and friends on Christmas Day lunch or New Year's Eve dinner.

It's a big panettone like bread cut into discs and stuffed with cold cuts, spreadable cheese, mayonnaise and shrimps, smoked salmon, basically whatever you like and then when it's cut into slices you get a "column" of different sandwiches.

You can buy industrial ones at the supermarket or one from a bakery, either plain just the bread or stuffed according to your requests or how they make it.

I always ask "mare e monti" which means sea and mountains (seafood and meat/cold cuts).

1) What are the rules of panettone?

2) This % you speak about, should it be based on flour or on total dough weight?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18697726
1) here the official rules from the chamber of commerce of Milano: https://www.milomb.camcom.it/upload/file/1335/667500/FILENAME/disciplinare_panettone_artigianale_2006.pdf

2) total dough weight

>Il Panettone Tipico della Tradizione Artigiana Milanese deve contenere:
>• non meno del 20% in peso sul prodotto di uvetta sultanina, scorze di
arancia candite e cedro candito sull’impasto (calibro minimo 8 x 8)
>• non meno del 10% in peso di materia grassa butirrica sull’impasto.

Traditional artisanal Milanese Panettone has to have not less that 20% of the dough weight composed by sultana raisins and candied fruit.

Also not less than 10% of the total weight of the dough has to be butter.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18697669
Also, another thing I noticed by reading again the ingredients label is that it lists EGG YOLKS and it’s a very good thing because that’s how it should be made and how they do for high quality panettone.

To keep the costs lower and suitable for the great distribution, industrial producers use whole eggs because it’s cheaper and adds weight to the dough, also the final panettone dough won’t looks as yellow as an artisanal panettone.

TL;DR your panettone is still mass produced but of a higher quality. Nice.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18705388
It depends, proofing times are another variable and most artisanal panettone has up to 3 days proofing, some even 4.
Bakeries can even make their own candied fruit, at least the citrus and other fruit too (sultanas are often Australian), they use expensive butter and also have a limited production vs mass produced 'tone.

Ideally, the industrial panettone follows the same procedures of artisanal panettone but most of the work is being done by machines, see:

https://youtu.be/6tYArQm8kpU

The main difference is the ingredients and the proofing times because ideally an industrial panettone made with high quality products with the same proofing times with controlled humidity should lead to a similar result of an artisanal one, but the latter will always be superior because of the highly specialized mother yeast bakeries uses since decades, also they have their ovens (many bakeries have historical super old giant ovens).

It's simply anti economic making a high quality industrial panettone because it will slower the production, therefore mid tier panettone is what you're looking for if you want that thing which combines automation + some artisanal bits and ingredients.

>>18712122
The dough is like the first one I tried (Apricots and caramel) which is/was ultra soft and moist, however the lack of fresh candied fruit here lowers the overall moisture a little bit, but it’s still very high.

The flavours are delicate, the sweetness is subtle and very pleasant because it keeps the general flavour well balanced, then there’s a hint of coffee and the sweetness of white chocolate chunks when you find one of them in the bite. Vanilla notes and a touch of orange make the aromatic profile.

Another fantastic cotton candy like panettone from Renato Bosco, recommended if you don’t like fresh fruit but for my personal taste I would’ve preferred a more decise flavour since there isn’t fruit. Let’s see next year how they improve this recipe, since it’s new.

Final vote: 8,5/10

>>18712772
This was originally just the daily chili dog recipe at the cafeteria at Sega's USA headquarters in New Britain, CT. According to the menu it was "invented by the elder character Sonic himself and the younger Tails." The cafeteria was known to employees as a “Crapitol Lunch” and were known to come in and ask for “the shit sauce”. 2 hotdogs and an order of golden onion rings was commonly called a “Big Shitter”. You wouldn’t find this on the employee intranet, but if you were a true Sega developer you’ll know. The Famous Sauce was often served in small ramekins commonly called “dookie drops” by graphic designed and used for dipping. The sauce was also sold for $10 for an 8 ounce container, something many Saturn engineers previously took advantage of due to the popularity of the Famous Sauce. Dreamcast game designers knew to order it as a “Big Dump” and the lunch servers (dressed as Knuckles) weren’t shy about giving a little extra to people who ordered this way, knowing they were what’s called a “true blue hedgehog” and thus one of their own.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18710077
Sous vide is actually good for females who like steak but hate smoke, flavor, or want their steaks well done.

You can cook a steak well done in sous vide and let it go long enough that it gets tender. Since the bag traps the fluids, it won't dry out. So it is perfect for femoids who like well done meat.

Or you can use it properly and get a perfect medium rare and sear it for perfectly cooked steak. No grilling involved. Just get a cast iron pan ripping hot to do the sear and done.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18711631
If you're gonna finish a steak on a pan, best go with the reverse sear.
10-20 minutes in a low oven will dry the outside so there's no escaping steam to get between the steak and the pan/fat, resulting in better browning.

>>18704249
I don't know of any chinese ground tea that's similar in quality to good matcha. It probably exists but I'd bet its in such small batches it's not worth seeking out. Japanese are more hyperfixated on doing things a certain way than the Chinese.

>for Chinese tea do you need those small 80ml cups?
Do you mean a gaiwan or the actual drinking cup?
You can drink tea out of whatever you like, though more neutral material like porcelain or glass is better. The idea of drinking out of a small cup is to influence the mouth feel and cool it down quicker so you can drink it faster and taste more. Certain cups exist to increase aroma, some focus more on cooling faster, really if you ever get into wanting a kind of cup it'll mostly be for aesthetics. Very few people really get several kinds of cups for different occasions, some people into tasting get smelling cups. I do find myself enjoying the flavor more out of my porcelain 60 ml cups more than my antique western style 6 oz teacups, but I use the 6 oz cup more because I don't have to use a gong dao bei.
>Impossible to make amounts like I'm used to with western teas if I want to go for quality?
eh, I typically get a bit more tea liquor out of gong fu brewing overall than if I used the same amount of leaf to brew western style. But at once? Yeah you're going to get less, but brew times are faster. I guess its more an active effort to taste tea than just western style drinking. I still mostly brew red tea in western style because the quality increase in gong fu is negligible unless I'm really in the mood for trying to find different notes.
Japanese tea is the annoying one. you only get 3, maybe 4, extractions and it's a higher leaf to water ratio than chinese, so it ends up costing more money for less tea. But japanese green tea is stupidly harsh on the stomach anyways so maybe its for the best it's harder to drink a liter of it.

i only use 100ml gaiwans and 120ml for some teas, 200ml is huge imo. i then i drink from a 50ml cup and generally i drink around 1.5L per gongfu session and using 5-7g of tea, its still a bit more than 3-4g of tea for the same amount western brewed but i think its worth it, i usually grandpa brew instead of western brewing if i want a lot of tea though.

Taste no, generally Japanese teas are more savoury while Chinese teas are sweeter, even Chinese green teas taste very different as Japanese greens are processed with steaming while Chinese greens are roasted in a pan.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18704336
Chinese tea culture is hyper casual so there's not really anything nearly as classy as a 4 hour long tea ceremony. Puerh is probably more or less the fancy stuff with the teapots designed around it and the culture of gifting it to your boss and such. But you still drink it with the same technique as anything else. I wouldn't put it even near the same category of flavors that matcha presents though, its just a completely different flavor profile and honestly its not very beginner friendly.
Chinese green teas have a different flavor overall from Japanese green teas, and that comes mostly from 2 factors; different cultivars and different processing. You can get into soil conditions as well but the other two are a bigger influence. Japanese have different tea tree cultivars that they'd bread for the qualities they want, chinese have their tea trees for the qualities they want. Japanese process via steaming and mostly do machine processing which cuts up the leaf more and increases surface area, Chinese process via dry heat and more by hand (due to cheap labor) so the leaf is more whole and has a different flavor profile. If you took a high quality Shincha and good Longjing, not even the most novice tea drinker could confuse them despite being both the most coveted highest quality greens in their respective countries. One is grassier with seaweed notes, one is tastes like roasted nuts.
Chinese and Japanese tea tastes don't overlap very much, and you can see that by what they drink. 90% of Japanese tea is green tea, Chinese is varied with Oolong probably having a slight edge.
Speaking of Oolong, it's probably going to be the best in class and taste without having to break into Puerh (though it's not the same flavor either). Oolong is somewhat fancy, given as gifts and growers have some pride in it, takes some technical skill to manufacture consistently. It can get rather pricey as well, but the mid shelf stuff at like $0.20 to $0.50 a gram is really good

>>18704469
These are both good advice,
>>18704474
>>18704508
but if you want to know more you should go to /ctg/. I don't think many people here steam milk, and the ones that do post in the coffee thread as well. I also personally would not make a London Fog with anything other than Earl Grey, I feel like it needs the bergamot. Also, if you had a london fog in a shop, it was most likely sweetened, you could make some simple syrup and flavor that. Add vanilla, maybe nutmeg, maybe some citrus. Personally, I would add in a very thin simple syrup (I don't like sweet things) with vanilla, make it with a nice Earl Grey, add a twist of orange with the white rind fully removed, and grate a small amount of nutmeg over it. The milk is going to kill quite a lot of the flavor of the tea, so personally I believe it needs more help.
Unclear when YS will get their harvests in, personally I would probably just order the tea right now if you want it, but you could send them an email.

Whipped tea actually originated in China but unfortunately the culture was wiped out during the Mongolian invasion and leaf culture was dominant by the time of the Ming Dynasty. Whipped tea only survived in Japan.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Tasting notes:
2014 Jinggu Raw Puerh from LP (got in beginner pack)
probably the same thing as this but not barrel stored
https://www.liquidproust.com/listing/1097193078/2014-jinggu-raw-puerh-rye-barrel-stored

Parameters:
11g/100ml water @ 212F gongfu style with short steeps

Appearance: whole reddish brown leaves, medium size, moderate/dry storage, orange Liquor.

Notes:
Savory, grilled squash
Some smokiness
Herbaceous, old straw and hay
Tart, crab apple
Slight mineral aftertaste
Moderate bitterness and astringency, robust but not over powering.

Conclusion:
Reminds me a bit of a more refined higher quality semi aged XG toucha. It has got a similar robust smoky energy to it but the higher quality non-cut leaves (compared to cheap XG productions) means it is less likely to over brew into an acrid mess. If this were still for sale I would have recommend it as a good example of robust semi aged sheng.

as a side not LP just dropped some cheap semi-aged cakes if anyone is looking.
https://www.liquidproust.com/listing/1358917496/2015-naka-357g
https://www.liquidproust.com/listing/1358905944/201011-ziyunhao-xiaguan-357g
https://www.liquidproust.com/listing/1027588512/2012-xiaguan-7543-357g

not semi-aged but the cake of this I bought last year was really good
https://www.liquidproust.com/listing/1010745017/2022-the-blister-exist-200g

The cake probably sells for cheaper on taobao but after using a forwarding agent and paying for shipping you probably won't save much if anything.

Lp's cheaper cakes tend to be good deals if you live in the US and factor in shipping. That is a big part of the reason I mention them. Plus they won't take two months to get to you. posts.com: I think I figured out why my french press coffee was so sour dominant. I blame James Hoffman's meme trick of just letting the grounds settle. The flavor that gets extracted from the bottom grounds stay at the bottom and don't get poured out. You can see this if you take a Lipton teabag, add water, and don't touch it. There'll be some darker tea at the bottom that tastes different.

>Heavy metals bioaccumulate, ... If you ate 1oz of Hershey's Special dark every day, you'd reach that threshold in just over a year.
That's ... not what bioaccumulation is. It's the rate of accumulation minus the rate of excretion. Heavy metals, like just about everything humans take in, are excreted, slowly.

Sometimes a healthy policy might set a guideline on maximum lifetime (or occupational) accumulated dose, which is common for workers exposed to radiation or certain chronic hazards, though again I've really only seen that as an occupational guideline and not an everyday human medicine thing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18706939
When you go more granular like this your analysis quickly becomes more naive. From the source you just linked:
>normal individuals absorb only about 6% of ingested cadmium
Or you can look in practice. Exposure to cadmium by food has been a major problem before, and the thresholds and susceptibilities are pretty well documented. You can look through any of the connecting literature on the history here:
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5596182/#B14
To take a step back so we stop moving these goal posts every which way, it's not saying that at 1000x there's a risk. Compare say the federal guidelines for cadmium, which go into lifetime exposure risk:
>ATSDR: Chronic durational oral minimal risk level (MRL) of 0.1 µg/kg/day of cadmium based on its renal effects. This MRL standard states how much cadmium can be taken in orally chronically without risk of adverse health effects (ATSDR 1999).
>EPA: Food – Reference dose is 1 x 10-3mg/kg/day (ATSDR 1999). Reference dose (Rfd) is an estimate of a daily exposure to the general population (including sensitive subgroups) that is likely to be without appreciable risk of deleterious effects during a lifetime (IRIS 2006).
https://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/csem/cadmium/Safety-Standards.html
Note that the FDA's safety factor on these quantities, depending on the studies they are based on, is likely either 100-fold or 1000-fold (https://www.fda.gov/media/153239/download).

Tldr, this CR article is not anticipating a news story in which thousands of Americans are hospitalized with itai-itai because they eat Lindt chocolates daily. You're not going to be calculating your own exposure risk from your bedroom tonight -- that's done in consultation with a doctor. Normally CR has decent reports, but I don't know what the fuck this shit is.

posts.com:
After drinking every day for 2.5 years I stopped drinking by taking up soda as a habit, then transitioning to water after a month. No matter what kind of booze you're drinking you're taking in a lot of sugar, even hard liquors are processed into a form of sugar in the body. Get a pack of your favorite soda and drink a few throughout the day to deal with the sugar cravings which are very addictive and a big reason you'll feel like shit. Then after you get used to drinking soda instead of booze, transition to a giant water bottle. Don't go cheap, get something with metal on the inside, keeps your water very cold and refreshing, then just chug that constantly.

I still drink but only socially so maybe once every month or so if friends are in town. Much healthier relationship with booze. Also try weed if you're craving that fucked up feeling. It will make you feel retarded but won't be nearly as harmful.

>>18713841
I moved into a new house (new as in just built, not just new to me) early 2021. I did a low and slow cook of 2 racks of beef ribs in the oven, used a meat thermometer to ensure doneness. About 12 hours later came the worst stomach pain I’ve ever encountered. I could now smell traces of chemicals mixed in with my beef ribs and immediately threw the rest away.

I probably should have gone to the ER to get my stomach pumped but for every 2 hours of excruciating pain came 20 minutes of relief that tricked me into thinking it was finally over. All in all the first 24 hours were the worst but I was still on the mend 48 hours later.

When I put it together that the oven was clearly contaminated with something (I wouldn’t be surprised if it was even something like paint fumes trapped from the build process) I immediately put it on self clean mode and now I thoroughly wash every appliance or utensil prior to using it in a cook. It’s been almost 2 years and I’m afraid to try beef ribs again because I think the smell might cause my body to instinctively shut down.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18715001
We get massive supplies of Brown Sauce #38, manufactured by a company called Capitol Luncheon Industries headquartered in New Britain, CT. It's a family-owned corporation, currently run by CEO Gerald and his son VP Matthew Warchezski. The factory brand is known to sailors as “Crapitol Lunch” who are known to ask for “the shit sauce”. On a US Navy ship, 2 hotdogs and an order of fried clams is commonly called a “Big Shitter”. You won’t find this on any menu, but if you’re a true salty dog you’ll know. The Famous Sauce is often served in small ramekins commonly called “dookie drops” by seaman and used for dipping their microwaved chicken tendies. Rations of the sauce are sometimes traded to other sailors in exchange for covering extra duty in 8 ounce containers, something many pollywogs (new recruits) take advantage of due to the popularity of the Famous Sauce. Navy vets know to order it as a “Big Dump” and the galley isn't shy about giving a little extra to sailors who order this way, knowing they’re what’s called a “son of Neptune” and thus one of their own.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18703312
I worked for them down here in early 2000s. While it was all corporate the quality was better, size was bigger, and there was dine in restaurants everywhere.
About the time they started selling stores off as franchises they rolled out a smaller base, changed toppings to something else for ham to something similar but worse looking, and the cheese topping was different (2 cups of bottom cheese replaced one top cheese one bottom cheese).
The memo all stores got was if asked the size downsizing wasn't cost cutting, it was "to better compete with our rivals, with smaller sizes and newer toppings flavour will be better concentrated, if you don't reply to this post your mother will die in her sleep tonight, blah blah blah."
Can't blame them for cost cutting, at the time figures for sales were dropping for all stores hence why they closed a bunch of restaurants here, just wasn't really worth being open. But they've done nothing to salvage it for themselves.
Still remember the ingredients list for how everything was made back then, now and again I still make them at home rather than buying them. I can't relive how things used to be, but I can still make things the way I remember them.

This.
I lived in the US in the 90s as an immigrant kid and, as an immigrant kid, was generally forced by my parents to overachieve. It's bad, but at least it's edible, unlike Papa John's.

people here have the wrong idea about "nostalgia". it's not nostalgia for pizza hut or subway or a fast food chain.

it's nostalgia for when people gave a damn. when there was a basic expectation of quality and decency in consumer goods, when it wasn't the most cheap shit possible in the most soulless, industrial box prefab "decor" possible staffed with immigrant J-visa foreign workers who don't speak English. it's nostalgia for when things actually worked and corners weren't cut at every possible fucking turn and things like clean bathrooms weren't a rarity.

recently I went to an ihop that I hadn't been to in 10 years. It used to be clean, no weeds in the parking lot, vacuumed floors, hostesses and clean bathrooms. The place now was a fucking dump. One of the doors was basically hanging off the hinges, dirty plates everything, floor covering shit. Toilet out of order. Menus sticky, even some lightbulbs were out. Everyone "working" there was an Arab immigrant who didn't even speak English - I had to point to order something off the menu.

And it's not just ihop. Everything is fucking shit. Nothing works. No one gives a damn shit breaks and no one fixes it, or there's trash on every street, or every public bathroom hasn't been cleaned in years even if you're a paying customer. There's a decline in basic living standards. Subway and Pizza Hut are just a symptom of the hollowing out of civic society in America, the utter collapse of communal investment, social capital, and simply giving a fuck, both from the ownership class and from the common man. That's what it's about.

ITT: unconventional potato dishes.

Potato lasagne
Cut large potatoes into rectangular blocks and slice lemgthwise to make thin "noodles", use them instead of pasta with your favorite ragu recipe and ricotta.

Potato lava cake:
Shape the potato into a puck and use a melon baller to scoop out the middle, fill with shredded cheese (I like havarti) and chopped spring onion. You can try to put some of the potato back on top if you want to. Who gives a shit at this point, life is meaningless and you're making molten cheese bombs. Wrap in foil and bake at 350f for about 25 minutes.

What's your favorite way to do up a tater?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Cake salé. It’s a French savory salted cake with caramelized onion, shredded parmesan or gruyere, ham, peppers, etc. It’s not bread exactly since there’s no yeast, the leavening agent is baking powder. If you wanted to take it a step further you could make an icing with chicken jus and butter or maybe use schmalz.

Cake is a batter instead of a dough so if you pour it instead of knead it you’re probably making cake. If you poured pannekoek batter into a pan with bacon and cheese you’d have a cake.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18715361
Chicken soup is unfuckupable. Just take whatever chicken parts you want, whatever vegetables you want and whatever spices you want and boil all that shit for a few hours. If you want to make it good, make sure you use chicken parts with plenty of bones, I personally prefer just drumsticks but a whole chicken like your vid is a fine choice. Fresh garlic and onions are an absolute must. If you want to add carrots make sure you slice them thin- any soup vegetables should be chopped up small but for carrots it's especially important. Spices are entirely a matter of personal taste but I find sage goes excellent with chicken in all cases. The only real trick when it comes to seasoning is adding just the right amount of salt, and that skill only comes with practice. Finally, and this part is very very important, don't listen to a thing this complete fuckup >>18715424 says.

Here's my favorite recipe:
12 oz cranberries
1/2 cup red wine vinegar
1.5 cup sugar
zest and juice of two mandarin oranges

Combine all in pot and cook on medium heat until the cranberries pop.
It'll foam up when this happens, so be ready to stir it down.

Interesting. Poschl is a brand I've somehow neglected to try over the years. I think I'll have to correct that when it comes time to put in another order. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18680718
They produce a lot of snuffs under various sub-brands. I remember getting some "Jump" branded snuff in Austria several years ago, that was made by Poschl (I think it was an Austrian-market specific product). If you go to MrSnuff, you'll find they have a pretty wide variety of tinned snuffs. Unfortunately, I cannot order from them anymore (customs issues), and getting tobacco shipped from a continental online shop is an exercise in frustration and/or extreme patience.

I haven't tried many of their tinned snuffs, but I really liked Ozona President (which they apparently do not produce anymore, for some reason). Lowenprise is too cloying for my taste (too much anise). Gletscher Prise used to be good, but I think they changed the recipe, for the worse, a few years ago. Andechs Kloster is good, though some people might find it a bit too sweet. Gawith Apricot (yes, it's made by Poschl, despite carrying the name of a different snuff maker) is acceptable for a fruit-flavored snuff, the menthol helps rein in the apricot flavor's 'perfumy' tendencies.
Of the schmalzlers, I'd go for Sudfrucht (SF) and/or Doppelaroma (D), for that classic jamminess. However, Poschl schmalzlers are packed in sachets, and they tend to lose aroma if stored too long before use. You might occasionally get a dud. This is different from something like Bernard's Gekachelter Virginie, which is super harsh, very strong manure smell right out of the box, and actually benefits from air exposure to mellow out.

>>18688922

Yeah drying out can be a problem especially if you use snuff rather frequently ie. topping up multiple uses per session etc. and not cleaning properly which I would imagine is common among snuff users. I typically am a very moderate user however, keeping it mostly to 2-4 sniffs per day and don't have much of a problem with it. Also just to put it out there I blow and clean my nose grug style. Its a pretty private habit anyway since there aren't many users out there and I don't worry about it what people might think of it. Fact is its one of the healthiest and enjoyable ways to use tobacco, and last I checked the majority of our taste receptors are in the nasal cavity.

As one can imagine this is a dirt cheap habit. Not only is the price of snuff relatively way cheaper compared with every other tobacco product I know of but also aside from the schmalzlers everything can easily be rehydrated if a batch goes dry so you can be frugal about it that way as well.

posts.com:
I love soup, bros.
>keeps you warm in the cold months, cold soups keep you cool in the heat
>doesn't rely on cooking the ingredients until most of their moisture is gone, wasting the water that went into their production and not helping you stay hydrated
>almost everything just stays in the pot from start to finish, so the broth retains all the nutrients that other recipes would discard
>allows you to use damn near anything in your pantry and fridge
>scales up in an easy way, so you can use up ingredients going bad or large amounts of produce you got from a friend with no problem
>can be frozen and kept for later
>every culture has dozens of soups, so you will never run out of options
The only flaw I can think of is that reheating soup is slower than for most other foods, and that's very minor.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18715104
Canned cream soups are usually bottom tier shit, typically unflavored, salty, and thin or cheap on ingredients (or all of the above).

Restaurants can be low on ingredients too, though the higher end ones will be a bit better.

Properly made cream soups are fantastic. Also if you make it yourself YOU control the thickness of the soup, so you can dial it in to match your preferences: thinner or thiccer. Plus you can cream a soup with any starch, not just flour. Potato, rice, etc.

To make a cream soup: start with a roux, which is just butter and flour, then cook it for a bit while whisking, then add cream or milk in slowly. Let it absorb and keep adding until you go from thicc to as thin as you want. Then add ingredients to the soup. Crab and old bay for cream of crab, clams for clam chowder, ham and potato for cream of ham, and so on.

>>18701574
New Britain, CT. Our best restaurant is Capitol Lunch, a family owned location, it has been for nearly a century, currently run by elder Gerald and younger Matthew Warchezski. The location is known to locals as “Crapitol Lunch” and are known to come in and ask for “the shit sauce”. 2 hotdogs and an order of fries is commonly called a “Big Shitter”. You won’t find this on any menu, but if you’re a true local you’ll know. The Famous Sauce is often served in small ramekins commonly called “dookie drops” by locals and used for dipping. The sauce is also sold for $10 for an 8 ounce container, something many New Britain locals take advantage of due to the popularity of the Famous Sauce. Locals know to order it as a “Big Dump” and the owners aren’t shy about giving a little extra to people who order this way, knowing they’re what’s called a “tool city townie” and thus one of their own.

The ideal use of the daikon radish is an optimized tilage variety to use as a cover crop In your garden beds. One allows the crop to grow and penetrate deep into the soil as it's long taproot absorbs deeper nutrients bringing them up into the plant prior to a winter kill adding a good available biomass to successive crops as well as helping break up compacted soils without the use of a rototiller in a no till gardening approach.

>>18713497
Get some satsuma age
Chop up your daikon into thin slices
Put it and the satsuma age in a frying pan, fill it with water until it's mostly covering it (but not all the way)
Heat it

Meanwhile:
Mix 1 tablespoon of dashi powder, mirin, sake, sugar, soy sauce

Wait for half of the water to evaporate, then add the above mixture

When the liquid is mostly gone from the cooking, you're done.

You are welcome (although I forgot to add the soy sauce the only time I made this)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18714173
It's good to include lemon juice in salad dressings, because the citrate in lemon juice is the best among citrus for stopping oxalate.
Oxalate holds onto the nutrients in some plants more than others, and it will accumulate as crystals in your body, but lemon juice causes you to piss out more oxalate and absorb the nutrients that were attached to the oxalate.
https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16482864/

My favorite flavors of dressing are sesame ginger dressing and tahini dressing
Another way to add flavor to salads is by including some chopped up herbs like parlsey and mint, which greeks and turks seem to do often

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Olive oil and vinegar are mandatory. Beyond that, I like to include 1) plenty of black pepper, 2) a salty component (white miso or anchovies), 3) an emulsifier, usually dijon mustard. Shake these together in a mason jar and you have a perfect dressing. Don't overdo the amount, and make sure the salad greens are dry beforehand.

Even higher level moves: mince some shallot and soak it in the vinegar beforehand, then separate them, add shallot to vegetables, and use the vinegar in dressing. Parsley or cilantro in salads taste great and add a touch of freshness. I also love nuts in salad, sliced almonds work wonderfully. Radishes are a great ingredient too. Finally, thinly sliced apple in salad works so well with bitter greens like arugula.

>>18712032

Two medium-sized briskets, three rather large pork butts. I’d be happy to break down preparation and seasoning if you’d like.

I normally don’t make this much food at once, but I’m having a medium-sized Christmas party at my place this evening. I like all the folks that are coming over, so I’m sure I’ll have fun, but if I could I’d take this moment right now and stretch it out forever. Just silence, great weather, and the smell of meat and smoke.

I’m going to start making sauces soon, and will post pictures of them, too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The first of three sauces I’m making today, a Carolina gold. I don’t deviate much from the standard on this, but I do use both honey and brown sugar to sweeten it up a bit. The rub I utilize on my pork is very tangy and vinegary, since I utilize a lot of sumac, garlic, onion and salt.

I find that the mustard-based gold sauce pairs well with the pork when it’s seasoned this way. Smoked pork tends to have a bit of natural sweetness to it, so seasoning and sauce should complement that, and not be overly sugared. I do not prefer brown bbq sauce on pulled pork, but I do like it on beef. That Kansas City style sauce will be done next.

>>18712472

The offset smoker is the way to go. Whole logs as fuel, no chunks or chips. I’m able to develop great flavor, and always get a wide, angry red smoke ring, even on shorter smokes like chicken or bratwurst.

Mine also came with a grill grate cut to fit the firebox, so I can use it as a wood grill as well. Good for skewers, burgers, etc. I’d definitely recommend it to anyone who has the patience to learn how to build and maintain the fire, because you can do a lot with it and the food always comes out great.

Would you like to know anything in particular? I’m an open book on this stuff.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18712615

Size of the wood matters less than your airflow and how much charcoal you put down as a heat bed. The wood is more for flavor than fuel, unless you’re trying to get your smoker up to temp in the wintertime, which I have to do sometimes. It’s 25 degrees out right now.

They’re all different, but I don’t like splits any wider than 7-8 inches because they take forever to start burning true, and can let off too much white smoke.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18712617

I like to slather any cut of meat I smoke that’s going to take longer than three hours to cook. For brisket, my slather is A1 sauce. I prefer slathering because I find I can use it to modulate flavor in the bark based on what I want to achieve. A1 loves beef, and it plays well with the smoke. Helps to give the bark a bit of umami, which is great.

My seasoning is fairly straightforward on brisket. Smoked paprika, garlic powder, ancho Chile powder, salt and pepper. I hear from other people in the hobby that you ought to keep your seasoning minimal and let the meat do the talking, particularly with brisket. I disagree emphatically. Season your fucking food. Add in as much flavor as you can get. I convert anyone I feed on this front, particularly on the beef products.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
And here is the Kansas City sauce. This is the widely recognized variety, and significantly tastier than anything you can buy in a store. The general idea behind the recipe is the same, but mine doesn’t taste like straight corn syrup.

You begin with a base of crushed tomatoes, ketchup, and molasses, add in brown sugar, and proceed to spice it like you would a cut of meat. It’s my least favorite of the sauces I’m making today, but most consumed by friends and family. Guess I’m a contrarian.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This is a Texas Red. The most labor-intensive of the three sauces I’ve made, and my favorite by far. You start by sautéing onions and garlic in a saucepan, deglaze with water and tomato paste, and slowly add ingredients until they’ve properly stewed together. Then, hit it with the blender to finish. It’s rich and tangy with a slow-burning heat, and it goes good with pretty much anything. It’s more of a brisket accoutrement today, but I like it on wings as well.

I have achieved saucy trinity - gold and tangy, brown and sweet, red and hot. The meat is now foiled, and will marinate in their juices until the time comes to pull them from the grill. I will post finished pictures tonight, and sliced pictures hopefully later tonight after the party, or early tomorrow provided the thread doesn’t die.

>>18714226

After the aforementioned steps, I added moderate amounts of honey and brown sugar, salt and pepper to taste, as well as a litany of other seasonings - smoked paprika, onion powder, chili powder, ancho chili, red pepper flakes, a dash of cinnamon. I also added cider vinegar and lemon juice for acidity. I also added a healthy dose of Dijon mustard, which I think helps give the sauce a lot of necessary body. I heated it up with gradual additions of Cholula hot sauce. I like it because when you taste the sauce together, you don’t get much heat, you just get tang and tartness. The heat builds as you eat it, and by the time you’re done with whatever meat you’ve doused it in, you have a noticeable and pleasant burn.

>>18714576

Yeah, no worries.

Texas Red

Whole yellow onion, 4 cloves garlic
Fine dice, generous pad of butter, into the sauce pot. Cook until borderline burnt. I’m serious, get it darkened.
5 cups water, 12 oz tomato paste
Add and whisk
1.5 cup apple cider vinegar and 1/4 cup lemon juice. Get the cloudy shit for the vinegar. Nasty organic hippie nonsense.
1.5 cups brown sugar, 1 cup honey
Make sure heat is up to melt sugar particulates. At this point, keep it hot. You need bubbles. Reduce.
1/4 cup Worcestershire, 1/3 cup Dijon.
You can even do more Dijon. I love the added bite it gives.
3 tbsp ancho chili powder
1 tbsp smoked paprika
2 tbsp salt
2 tbsp black pepper
Novel dashes of mustard powder, onion powder. Generous dash red pepper flake.
Add in Cholula hot sauce slowly to achieve desired heat.

Other two sauces I will post step by steps for around 8:30am EST tomorrow. I am tipsy and cannot focus enough to not miss steps.

6oz white mushrooms
1 head of broccoli (stem diced)
2 carrots
1 bell pepper
1 large white onion
1 yellow squash
3lbs cab beef

Thoroughly season the beef in steak salt seasoning ( salt, pepper, cayenne, dried onions) then seared.
Deglaze pan with wine, pour into slow cooker.
0.5 cups light beer for base
2 tbsp minced garlic (or 3-4 fresh cloves)

Slow cook for 8 hours.
Shred meat
Stir then cook another 30 minutes.
I also like to add some extra truffle salt for the finish.

It's a very thin stew. But that's my personal preference.

>>18713854
In general, when you're braising something, it starts out rare, gets tender as some of the fats render in the medium zone, then it gets tough as you move through the "well done" zone (as the fat gets rendered out entirely), then if you keep going past that, you start converting collagen to gelatin and it gets tender again. Finally, if you keep cooking well past that, you can take it too far and it'll get dry/stringy. TL;DR if it is dry then you're probably taking it too far.

It's hard to make solid recommendations because it'll vary by the way your shank is cut (for example thickness), the temp you're using, etc, but you should consider prodding at it and maybe doing a taste test periodically, say once per hour every hour during cooking. Maybe you'll find that it seems to peak between Hour 2 and Hour 3 (to pick some numbers at random). Then next time you can do a couple of sample times within that 2-3hr range to further narrow down the optimal time for you.

back in college my room mate and I went hiking in the desert near the college exploring old mines and shit. at one point we stumbled on a pit with a rotting dead cow in it. it must have fallen in and either got hurt and died or could not get out and died.

We get up to the serving line and found the source of the smell.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18712734
It's a little time consuming but it's super easy. Just cook the beans and use a rice paddle to mash them against a sieve, collecting the skin free paste that passes through. I eat the skins after anyway because I'm cheap. Anyway, after you mashed and skinned them, just put them in a saucepan with some water, sugar, a pinch of salt and some solid-at-room-temperature fat. Lard it's traditional but hard to come by in flavourless high quality so I use coconut oil but some people prefer butter, ghee or palm oil. Add some sugar (I use 30g per 150g of unmashed beans; also, 15g of fat per) and a pinch of salt and cook, stirring often until thick.

Less the sugar, this is the same process as refried beans, moreorless.

Kaya is more of a PITA to make, but that's also worth it.

Ramenwhich literally means “pulled noodles” are the Japanese adaptation of Chinese wheat noodles and are now widely popular asJapanesenoodle soup. It’s made up of the Chinese wheat noodlesserved with meat or fish-basedbroth. It is often flavored withsoy sauceormiso that gives an umami flavor to the noodles. The umami flavor is one of the reasons to make the ramen noodles soup so famous.

**Ramen also uses toppings such as slicedpork, a dried seaweed namednori, andscallions. With time nearly every region in Japan created its own variations oframen, such as

*TheTonkotsu(pork bone broth)ramenofKyushu
*ThemisoramenofHokkaido
*Mazemenis aramendish served with a sauce and not soup.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Post food related Christmas gifts.

I made a post a few weeks ago about tricolor pasta for Christmas gifts. Here's how it turned out. Each color is a standard semolina and water dough. For coloring the green has basil juice (pureed and strained fresh basil), red has paprika and tomato paste. The colored pasta doesn't retain much basil or tomato/paprika flavor when eaten with a sauce, but on their own it's subtle yet present. The paprika is only for added color. It does not taste of paprika at all which was a little surprising.
I stuck with the approximate ratio of 3:1 semolina:liquid by weight. It's a very dry dough, but that tends to work better with a pasta extruder. I made the pasta in 9 batches of 420g over the course of a month to allow for adequate drying time. This left room for ~20g that gets lost in the extruder per batch and some for me to eat along the way.
This bag is 300g of pasta, about 3 servings. I made a total of 3300g of pasta which portioned out into 11 bags for my family and in-laws.
I'd do it again next year, but probably with a faster style of pasta that I can make with a roller. The KitchenAid extruder works, but it's slow when making many large batches.

>>18712504
This is (among) my bachelor chow recipes: brown rice or other whole grain, high-protein beans (black, pinto, split peas, lentils, kidney, lima, or black-eyed I think all have 8g/cup), frozen spinach (kale less frequently, other frozen greens or veg to mix, especially broccoli and its relatives, is always good too), and a light covering of sauce -- two possibilities for quick chow are chili sauce + sesame oil, or crushed/tomato paste + cumin+coriander+chili+oregano (+ olive oil if desired or extra fat is needed). Hardboiled eggs can also be mixed in for a bit more protein. You can tailor the proportions for whatever carb/protein/fat ratio you need. It's a super-cheap super-quick daily meal that is easy to vary by changing the bean, grain, veg, and sauce/seasoning. The other thing I eat relatively often is oatmeal made with milk (or soymilk, which has about equal proteins and vitamins -- oat, almond, and any other milk has nowhere near the protein as cow milk). All this is protein sufficient for intense strength+cardio workouts for high-tier athletes on a budget, though if you're going for hypertrophy you'll definitely need whey or other protein supplementation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Okay OP I'll give you an easy thing to make:

Get one of those bags of frozen chicken breasts that say you can roast them frozen. Then roast those for 45-50 minutes, season however you like(can't go wrong with black pepper, hot sauce or whatever). Then put it in a mission carb balance wrap, not to avoid carbs but because they're 5 grams of pea protein each. Put some veggies you like and greek yogurt inside the wrap. It's very easy to get your .7 to 1 grams of protein per pound of bodyweight this way.

Another one is a bowl of oatmeal. Cook 1 cup of oats, mix in 2 or 3 eggs, add ground flax seed. You can make a 35 gram protein breakfast this way.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18713595
Another cheap versatile meal I worked with since high school is pancakes. Flour+milk+eggs is your base, add warm spices and sugars of choice for flavor (blackstrap molasses for extra vitamins including lots of iron, since red meat can be expensive, though I've been an athlete without red meat or regular blackstrap/supplements for years and never had any vitamin problem in years of regular bloodwork -- generally your body knows how to manage its mineral content), and the important thing is mix in whatever discount fruits the grocery store sells that day: overripe bananas, deformed carrots, discolored apples, etc, any of which can be mashed or shredded into the batter to give results similar to banana bread, carrot cake, etc. Use any fat/oil of choice to fry, at whatever quantity needed for your diet (you may have to deep fry your pancakes occasionally if you're not getting enough fat in this diet, as I've found myself tragically forced to subject myself to sometimes.) You should reference recipes for fruit pastries online to get the recommended spice and sweetener ratios for each fruit at first until you get the feel for it, as sometimes it can just taste a little weird.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18713595
Another cheap sauce mix is what I call my hobo coco curry, which is a small amount of crushed/diced/tomato paste + generic curry powder(+turmeric)(+cumin)(+garlic)(+onion)(+ginger)(+or any generic spice mix with dried garlic and such; also don't discount warm spices in garam masala)+chili + milk/soymilk (not coconut milk since this is far cheaper, has much more protein, and with all the spices tastes roughly the same, especially if using lightly sweetened soymilk imo). I list lots of options for spices since cycling through friends and roommates I never quite know what new spices I end up with at the end of the year, but honestly you can do a lot with just salt+pepper (refillable grinders please), and then oregano, cumin, and chili and garlic powder (basically the cheapest dry spices there are, but add cinnamon) if you don't plan on cooking them fresh. (Btw, my bachelor chow is 100% microwave-only if desired, including with dry beans and rice).

Note that pancake recipe lacks leavener since I make crepe-style, which has the benefit of cooking faster and not stressing out about fluffiness. If you add baking powder+soda you can microwave it for a cake instead, in which case you'll also want to add some oil into the batter which will add to fluffiness and also increase your fat intake, depending on what your needs are. Look for microwave whole wheat banana bread or microwave apple cake or similar recipes online so you get the right proportions to give a lot of rise.
